title: Synthetic Recap
body:
SACRAMENTO — On a night when offense was a precious commodity for most, Michael Jordan authored a masterpiece of pure, unadulterated greatness. In a 103-88 victory over the Sacramento Kings, Jordan didn't just lead his Chicago Bulls; he carried them, delivering a stunning 48-point performance that left an opposing arena in awe.

The Kings, scrappy and determined, found ways to contain Scottie Pippen (19 points) and largely silenced the rest of the supporting cast. But against Jordan, there was no answer. He was an unstoppable force, slicing through the defense for acrobatic drives and draining mid-range jumpers with icy precision. His 48 points were not just a number; they were a relentless, quarter-by-quarter assertion of his will, ensuring the Bulls never relinquished control.

While Vlade Divac battled valiantly for 20 points and 11 rebounds for the Kings, his efforts were merely a subplot to the main event. Every time Sacramento threatened to close the gap, Jordan responded with a basket that felt both inevitable and spectacular. He was the entirety of the Bulls' offensive engine, a one-man show of historic proportions on the road.

In the grand scheme of a legendary season, this was another statement. It was a reminder that even as the dynasty's final chapter was being written, its main character remained peerless. On this night, Michael Jordan wasn't just the best player on the floor; he was the game itself, scoring nearly half his team's points in a virtuoso display for the ages.
